# Infant Care in California (0-18 months)

## Licensing Requirements
- **Staff-to-child ratio**: 1:3 or 1:4 depending on license type
- **Group size**: Maximum 12 infants per group
- **Caregiver qualifications**: Specific infant care training required

## What to Look For
- Safe sleep practices (back to sleep, firm surface)
- Individual feeding schedules
- Diaper changing protocols
- Daily communication with parents

## Cost Considerations
Infant care is typically the most expensive:
- Licensed centers: $1,500-3,500/month
- Family childcare: $1,000-2,000/month
- Regional Market Rate caps apply for subsidies

## Subsidy Availability
- CalWORKs covers infant care
- Alternative Payment covers infants
- Some programs have infant priority

## Health Requirements
- Immunization schedule for infants
- Well-baby checkups documented
- Breastfeeding accommodation required

# Toddler Care Programs (18 months - 3 years)

## Licensing Requirements
- **Staff-to-child ratio**: 1:4 to 1:6
- **Group size**: Maximum 12-18 toddlers
- **Space requirements**: 35 sq ft per child indoors

## Developmental Focus
- Language development activities
- Gross motor skill development
- Social-emotional learning
- Potty training support

## Program Types
- **Full-day care**: 6am-6pm typical
- **Part-day programs**: Morning or afternoon
- **Drop-in care**: Limited availability

## What Parents Should Ask
- Toilet training policy
- Nap/rest schedule
- Outdoor play time
- Discipline approach
- Transition to preschool

## Subsidy Rates
Toddler rates are typically 80-90% of infant rates.

## Transition Planning
Most programs transition toddlers to preschool rooms around age 2.5-3.

# Preschool Programs (3-5 years)

## Program Types

### State Preschool
- Free for income-eligible families
- Part-day (3 hours) or full-day
- School readiness curriculum
- Must be 3 by September 1

### Head Start
- Federal program, free
- Comprehensive services (health, nutrition, family)
- Income-based eligibility (100% FPL)
- Full-day options available

### Private Preschool
- Various philosophies (Montessori, Reggio, play-based)
- Costs vary widely
- May accept subsidies

### Transitional Kindergarten (TK)
- Free public school program
- For children turning 5 between Sept 2 and Feb 2
- Expanding to universal TK by 2025-26

## Licensing Ratios
- **Staff-to-child**: 1:8 to 1:12
- **Teacher qualifications**: 12-24 units ECE minimum

## School Readiness
- California Preschool Learning Foundations
- Kindergarten transition programs
- Assessment and portfolio documentation

# School-Age Care (5-13 years)

## Program Types

### Before School Care
- Typically 6:30am to school start
- Homework time, breakfast
- Structured and free play

### After School Care
- School end to 6pm typical
- Homework help
- Enrichment activities
- Recreation

### School Break/Summer Care
- Full-day programs during breaks
- Summer camps (day camps)
- Specialized programs

## Funding Sources
- **ASES**: After School Education & Safety
- **21st CCLC**: 21st Century Community Learning Centers
- **Expanded Learning**: State-funded programs

## Subsidy Coverage
- CalWORKs covers school-age care
- Alternative Payment available
- Sliding scale fees common

## Licensing
- **Ratios**: 1:14 for school-age
- **Space**: Less stringent than younger ages
- **Exempt programs**: Some school-based programs exempt

## Finding Programs
- Check with school district
- R&R agency referrals
- Parks and recreation departments

# Teen Care and Youth Programs (13+ years)

## Why Older Youth Need Programs
- After school supervision
- Academic support
- Prevention of risky behaviors
- Career exploration
- Social development

## Program Types

### Teen Centers
- Drop-in recreation
- Homework help
- Social activities
- Leadership programs

### Youth Development Programs
- 4-H
- Boys & Girls Clubs
- YMCA/YWCA
- City recreation programs

### Career and Job Training
- Summer youth employment
- Job shadowing
- Internships
- Vocational programs

## Subsidy Limitations
- Most childcare subsidies end at age 13
- Some special needs exceptions to age 21
- Alternative funding sources:
  - Workforce development
  - Recreation scholarships
  - Nonprofit programs

## Resources
- California Youth Connection
- Local parks and recreation
- School district programs
- Community-based organizations

# Mixed-Age Care Settings

## Family Childcare Homes
Often serve multiple ages in one setting.

### Small Family Childcare
- Up to 8 children
- May include provider's own children
- Mixed ages common

### Large Family Childcare
- Up to 14 children
- Assistant required
- More structured age groupings

## Benefits of Mixed-Age
- Sibling care together
- Older children mentor younger
- Family-like environment
- Flexible scheduling

## Considerations
- Different developmental needs
- Supervision challenges
- Activity planning complexity
- Sleep schedule coordination

## Subsidy in Family Childcare
- Same subsidy rates as centers
- Regional Market Rate applies
- License-exempt family can also receive subsidies

## Quality Indicators
- QRIS participation
- Training and credentials
- Learning environment
- Family engagement

# Children with Special Needs Care

## Inclusive Childcare Requirements
California law requires childcare programs to:
- Make reasonable accommodations
- Not discriminate based on disability
- Work with families on inclusion plans

## Special Needs Subsidy Provisions
- **Exceptional Needs Rate**: Higher reimbursement
- **Age extensions**: Care may extend beyond age 13
- **Respite care**: Additional support available

## Types of Special Needs Served
- Developmental delays
- Physical disabilities
- Autism spectrum
- Sensory impairments
- Medical conditions
- Behavioral challenges

## Finding Inclusive Care
- Regional Centers for assessment
- Special needs R&R referrals
- Early Start program (0-3)
- Special education preschool (3-5)

## Documentation Required
- IFSP (Individual Family Service Plan)
- IEP (Individual Education Program)
- Medical documentation
- Therapy recommendations

## Resources
- California Department of Developmental Services
- Local Regional Centers
- Early Start Family Resource Centers

# Newborn and Maternity Care Transitions

## Before Birth Planning
- Start childcare search during pregnancy
- Get on wait lists early
- Understand leave options

## California Family Leave
- **PDL**: Pregnancy Disability Leave (up to 4 months)
- **CFRA**: California Family Rights Act (12 weeks)
- **PFL**: Paid Family Leave (8 weeks at partial pay)

## Infant Care Timing
Most infant programs accept babies starting at:
- 6 weeks (some centers)
- 8-12 weeks (more common)
- 3 months (some family childcare)

## Breastfeeding Support
Providers must:
- Store breast milk properly
- Feed on parent's schedule
- Provide comfortable nursing space

## Transition Tips
- Start with short days
- Maintain communication
- Bring comfort items
- Be patient with adjustment

## Emergency Backup Care
- Some employers offer backup care
- Care.com Backup Care
- Family and friend support network
